answer_llm:
You're passing the ImageDataGenerator object (`train_gen`) to the model's fit method when you should be passing the dataset obtained from `flow_from_directory` (`train_ds`). 
The same applies to the validation data: you should use `test_ds` instead of `test_gen`.
answer_orig:
While training a Keras model you get the error “Failed to find data adapter that can handle input: <class 'keras.src.preprocessing.image.ImageDataGenerator'>, <class 'NoneType'>” you may have unintentionally passed the image generator instead of the dataset to the model
train_gen = ImageDataGenerator(rescale=1./255)
train_ds = train_gen.flow_from_directory(…)
history_after_augmentation = model.fit(
train_gen, # this should be train_ds!!!
epochs=10,
validation_data=test_gen # this should be test_ds!!!
)
The fix is simple and probably obvious once pointed out, use the training and validation dataset (train_ds and val_ds) returned from flow_from_directory
Added by Tzvi Friedman

answer_llm:
To execute the 'nvidia-smi' command in a loop without using the 'watch' command, you can use the following command:

```
nvidia-smi -l <N seconds>
```

Replace `<N seconds>` with the desired interval in seconds. For example, to run 'nvidia-smi' every 2 seconds, use:

```
nvidia-smi -l 2
```

This will continuously update the output of 'nvidia-smi' every 2 seconds until interrupted using CTRL+C.
answer_orig:
The command ‘nvidia-smi’ has a built-in function which will run it in subsequently updating it every N seconds without the need of using the command ‘watch’.
nvidia-smi -l <N seconds>
The following command will run ‘nvidia-smi’ every 2 seconds until interrupted using CTRL+C.
nvidia-smi -l 2
Added by Sylvia Schmitt

answer_llm:
The number of parameters in a Conv2d layer is calculated as: (kernel height * kernel width * number of input channels + 1 for bias) * number of filters. 

For example, a Conv2d layer with a 3x3 kernel, 3 input channels (RGB image), and 32 filters would have (3 * 3 * 3 + 1) * 32 = 896 parameters.
answer_orig:
Let’s say we define our Conv2d layer like this:
>> tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(32, (3,3), activation='relu', input_shape=(150, 150, 3))
It means our input image is RGB (3 channels, 150 by 150 pixels), kernel is 3x3 and number of filters (layer’s width) is 32.
If we check model.summary() we will get this:
_________________________________________________________________
Layer (type)                Output Shape              Param #
=================================================================
conv2d (Conv2D)             (None, 148, 148, 32)      896
So where does 896 params come from? It’s computed like this:
>>> (3*3*3 +1) * 32
896
# 3x3 kernel, 3 channels RGB, +1 for bias, 32 filters
What about the number of “features” we get after the Flatten layer?
For our homework model.summary() for last MaxPooling2d and Flatten layers looked like this:
_________________________________________________________________
Layer (type)                Output Shape              Param #
=================================================================
max_pooling2d_3       (None, 7, 7, 128)         0
flatten (Flatten)           (None, 6272)              0
So where do 6272 vectors come from? It’s computed like this:
>>> 7*7*128
6272
# 7x7 “image shape” after several convolutions and poolings, 128 filters
Added by Andrii Larkin
question: What determines the parameter count for a Conv2d layer?

answer_llm: The output shape of a Conv2d layer is determined by the input image size, kernel size, and padding. The example provided uses a 150x150 input image with a 3x3 kernel and no padding, resulting in a 148x148 output. The last value in the output shape (32) represents the number of filters used in the convolutional layer.

question: How do you calculate the number of features after the Flatten layer?

answer_llm: The output shape of the previous MaxPooling2d layer is (None, 7, 7, 128), meaning it outputs a 7x7 "image" with 128 filters.  Multiplying these dimensions (7 * 7 * 128) gives us 6272, which is the number of vectors in the Flatten layer.

answer_llm: The Sequential model API in Keras allows you to add layers to your model in a sequential order, where each layer has one input and one output tensor. The Functional model API, while allowing for the same sequential ordering of layers, is implemented in Alexey's videos using chained calls of different entities like "inputs", "base", "vectors", and "outputs".
answer_orig:
It’s quite useful to understand that all types of models in the course are a plain stack of layers where each layer has exactly one input tensor and one output tensor (Sequential model TF page, Sequential class).
You can simply start from an “empty” model and add more and more layers in a sequential order.
This mode is called “Sequential Model API”  (easier)
In Alexey’s videos it is implemented as chained calls of different entities (“inputs”,“base”, “vectors”,  “outputs”) in a more advanced mode “Functional Model API”.
Maybe a more complicated way makes sense when you do Transfer Learning and want to separate “Base” model vs. rest, but in the HW you need to recreate the full model from scratch ⇒ I believe it is easier to work with a sequence of “similar” layers.
You can read more about it in this TF2 tutorial.
A really useful Sequential model example is shared in the Kaggle’s “Bee or Wasp” dataset folder with code: notebook
Added by Ivan Brigida
Fresh Run on Neural Nets
While correcting an error on neural net architecture, it is advised to do fresh run by restarting kernel, else the model learns on top of previous runs.
Added by Abhijit Chakraborty

answer_llm:
To resolve out-of-memory (OOM) errors when using TensorFlow with an Nvidia GPU, you can try the following code snippet:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
  tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
  # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
  pass
```

This code sets the memory growth option for TensorFlow, which attempts to allocate only as much GPU memory as needed for the given operation.
answer_orig:
I found this code snippet fixed my OOM errors, as I have an Nvidia GPU. Can't speak to OOM errors on CPU, though.
https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/config/experimental/set_memory_growth
```
physical_devices = tf.configlist_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0],True)
except:
# Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
pass
```

answer_llm: The provided context states that `ImageDataGenerator` is not recommended for new Keras code and suggests using `image_dataset_from_directory` and `tf.data.Dataset` instead, but it does not explain why.
answer_orig:
From the keras documentation:
Deprecated: tf.keras.preprocessing.image.ImageDataGenerator is not recommended for new code. Prefer loading images with tf.keras.utils.image_dataset_from_directory and transforming the output tf.data.Dataset with preprocessing layers. For more information, see the tutorials for loading images and augmenting images, as well as the preprocessing layer guide.
Hrithik Kumar Advani

answer_llm: The command `echo ${REMOTE_URI}` returns nothing when the variable `REMOTE_URI` is not set in your current terminal session.
answer_orig:
Solution description
In the unit 9.6, Alexey ran the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} which turned the URI address in the terminal. There workaround is to set a local variable (REMOTE_URI) and assign your URI address in the terminal and use it to login the registry, for instance, REMOTE_URI=2278222782.dkr.ecr.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images (fake address). One caveat is that you will lose this variable once the session is terminated.
I also had the same problem on Ubuntu terminal. I executed the following two commands:
$ export REMOTE_URI=1111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001
$ echo $REMOTE_URI
111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001
Note: 1. no curly brackets (e.g. echo ${REMOTE_URI}) needed unlike in video 9.6,
2. Replace REMOTE_URI with your URI
(Bhaskar Sarma)
question: What does it mean when the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} returns nothing?

answer_llm: To set the REMOTE_URI variable, use the command `export REMOTE_URI=your_URI_address` replacing `your_URI_address` with your actual URI. Make sure to omit curly brackets when echoing the variable.

answer_llm: Use `aws ecr get-login-password` instead of `aws ecr get-login --no-include-email`.
answer_orig:
The command aws ecr get-login --no-include-email returns an invalid choice error:
The solution is to use the following command instead:  aws ecr get-login-password
Could simplify the login process with, just replace the <ACCOUNT_NUMBER> and <REGION> with your values:
export PASSWORD=`aws ecr get-login-password`
docker login -u AWS -p $PASSWORD <ACCOUNT_NUMBER>.dkr.ecr.<REGION>.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm: This error can occur when building a docker image from the Amazon python base image. Updating your docker desktop, restarting docker desktop and terminal before rebuilding the image, or running the command "DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0  docker build ." before building the image could potentially solve the problem.
answer_orig:
This error is produced sometimes when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image.
Solution description: The following could solve the problem.
Update your docker desktop if you haven’t done so.
Or restart docker desktop and terminal and then build the image all over again.
Or if all else fails, first run the following command: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0  docker build .  then build your image.
(optional) Added by Odimegwu David
question: What causes ERROR [internal] load metadata for public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.8?

answer_llm:
This question is about resolving an error when building a Docker image from the Amazon Python base image. To address this, try these steps:

1. **Update Docker Desktop:** Ensure you are using the latest version of Docker Desktop.
2. **Restart Docker:** Try restarting both Docker Desktop and your terminal, then rebuild the image.
3. **Use DOCKER_BUILDKIT:** If the issue persists, execute the command `DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0 docker build .` before building your image.
answer_orig:
This error is produced sometimes when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image.
Solution description: The following could solve the problem.
Update your docker desktop if you haven’t done so.
Or restart docker desktop and terminal and then build the image all over again.

(optional) Added by Odimegwu David

answer_llm: The command "!dir" can be used in a Windows Jupyter Notebook instead of "!ls -lh".
answer_orig:
When trying to run the command  !ls -lh in windows jupyter notebook  , I was getting an error message that says “'ls' is not recognized as an internal or external command,operable program or batch file.

Instead of !ls -lh , you can use this command !dir , and you will get similar output

answer_llm: Restart the kernel and only import `tflite_runtime.interpreter`.
answer_orig:
When I run   import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite , I get an error message says “ImportError: generic_type: type "InterpreterWrapper" is already registered!”
Solution description
This error occurs when you import both tensorflow  and tflite_runtime.interpreter  “import tensorflow as tf” and “import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite” in the same notebook.  To fix the issue, restart the kernel and import only tflite_runtime.interpreter " import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite".

answer_llm: The context provided doesn't have information about fixing the 'Windows version might not be up-to-date' error during a Docker build. It does suggest making sure Docker isn't being stopped by another program. However, there's no direct solution for the 'Windows version' error message itself.
answer_orig:
Problem description:
In command line try to do $ docker build -t dino_dragon
got this Using default tag: latest
[2022-11-24T06:48:47.360149000Z][docker-credential-desktop][W] Windows version might not be up-to-date: The system cannot find the file specified.
error during connect: This error may indicate that the docker daemon is not running.: Post
.
Solution description:
You need to make sure that Docker is not stopped by a third-party program.
Andrei Ilin

answer_llm: The provided context mentions a "pip version" error in the context of building a Docker image named "dino-dragon-model". It explains that the error might occur if an incompatible Python version is used for the "tflite_runtime" wheel. To resolve this, download the correct wheel file for your Python version from the provided link: https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp39-cp39-linux_x86_64.whl.
answer_orig:
When running docker build -t dino-dragon-model it returns the above error
The most common source of this error in this week is because Alex video shows a version of the wheel with python 8, we need to find a wheel with the version that we are working on. In this case python 9. Another common error is to copy the link, this will also produce the same error, we need to download the raw format:
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp39-cp39-linux_x86_64.whl
Pastor Soto

answer_llm: Numpy float32 values (arrays) returned by the model need to be converted to base-Python floats to make them "serializable".
answer_orig:
Problem:
While passing local testing of the lambda function without issues, trying to test the same input with a running docker instance results in an error message like
{‘errorMessage’: ‘Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable’, ‘errorType’: ‘Runtime.MarshalError’, ‘requestId’: ‘f155492c-9af2-4d04-b5a4-639548b7c7ac’, ‘stackTrace’: []}
This happens when a model (in this case the dino vs dragon model) returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values (arrays). They need to be converted individually to base-Python floats in order to become “serializable”.
Solution:
In my particular case, I set up the dino vs dragon model in such a way as to return a label + predicted probability for each class as follows (below is a two-line extract of function predict() in the lambda_function.py):
preds = [interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0], \
1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]]
In which case the above described solution will look like this:
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), \
float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
The rest can be made work by following the chapter 9 (and/or chapter 5!) lecture videos step by step.
Added by Konrad Muehlberg
question: Why does my lambda function pass local tests but fail on a running docker instance?

answer_llm: The 'Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable' error arises when a model returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values (arrays) which need to be converted to base-Python floats to become serializable.

question: What causes the 'Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable' error in my model?

answer_llm:
To make numpy float32 values JSON serializable, convert them to base-Python floats using the `float()` function. 

For example, if you have: 
`preds = [interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0], 1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]]`

You would change it to:
`preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]`

answer_llm: The error, "ValueError: Cannot set tensor: Got value of type UINT8 but expected type FLOAT32 for input 0, name: serving_default_conv2d_input:0", arises when the input 'X' is an integer data type, while the model expects a float (FLOAT32) data type.
answer_orig:
I had this error when running the command line : interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, x) that can be seen in the video 9.3 around 12 minutes.
ValueError: Cannot set tensor: Got value of type UINT8 but expected type FLOAT32 for input 0, name: serving_default_conv2d_input:0
This is because the X is an int but a float is expected.
Solution:
I found this solution from this question here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/76102508/valueerror-cannot-set-tensor-got-value-of-type-float64-but-expected-type-float :
# Need to convert to float32 before set_tensor
X = np.float32(X)
Then, it works. I work with tensorflow 2.15.0, maybe the fact that this version is more recent involves this change ?
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard
question: What causes the error when running the interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, x) command?

answer_llm:
To resolve the "ValueError: Cannot set tensor: Got value of type UINT8 but expected type FLOAT32" error, convert the variable `X` to a float32 data type using the following line of code: 

```python
X = np.float32(X)
```

This error occurs when the interpreter expects a float input but receives an integer.

Added by Mélanie Fouesnard
question: Does the version of TensorFlow used affect the solution for the interpreter.set_tensor error?

answer_llm:
To check file size in PowerShell, use:

```powershell
$File = Get-Item -Path path_to_file
$FileSize = (Get-Item -Path $FilePath).Length
Write-host "MB":($FileSize/1MB)
```

Replace "path_to_file" with the actual file path. This script gets the file size in bytes and then displays it in megabytes.
answer_orig:
To check your file size using the powershell terminal, you can do the following command lines:
$File = Get-Item -Path path_to_file
$FileSize = (Get-Item -Path $FilePath).Length
Now you can check the size of your file, for example in MB:
Write-host "MB":($FileSize/1MB)
Source: https://www.sharepointdiary.com/2020/10/powershell-get-file-size.html#:~:text=To%20get%20the%20size%20of,the%20file%2C%20including%20its%20size.
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

answer_llm:
To resolve the pip install error for the tflite runtime whl when building a Docker image on an M1 Mac, use the following build command:

```bash
docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model .
```

This command specifies the platform as `linux/amd64`, which is necessary for compatibility with the ARM architecture of the M1 Mac.
answer_orig:
Problem:
While trying to build docker image in Section 9.5 with the command:
docker build -t clothing-model .
It throws a pip install error for the tflite runtime whl
ERROR: failed to solve: process "/bin/sh -c pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/blob/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl" did not complete successfully: exit code: 1
Try to use this link: https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl
If the link above does not work:
The problem is because of the arm architecture of the M1. You will need to run the code on a PC or Ubuntu OS.
Or try the code bellow.
Added by Dashel Ruiz Perez
Solution:
To build the Docker image, use the command:
docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model .
To run the built image, use the command:
docker run -it --rm -p 8080:8080 --platform linux/amd64 clothing-model:latest
Added by Daniel Egbo

answer_llm:
- Check if your OS-Python version combination is supported: https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
- If your combination is not there, try installing a compatible `tflite_runtime` wheel from: https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
- For example: 
```bash
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
```
- If none of the above work, use TensorFlow's TFLite locally and Docker for Lambda testing.
answer_orig:
Problem: When trying to install tflite_runtime with
!pip install --extra-index-url https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/ tflite_runtime
one gets an error message above.
Solution:
fflite_runtime is only available for the os-python version combinations that can be found here: https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
your combination must be missing here
you can see if any of these work for you https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
and install the needed one using pip
eg
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
as it is done in the lectures code:
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/mlbookcamp-code/blob/master/course-zoomcamp/09-serverless/code/Dockerfile#L4
Alternatively, use a virtual machine (with VM VirtualBox, for example) with a Linux system. The other way is to run a code at a virtual machine within cloud service, for example you can use Vertex AI Workbench at GCP (notebooks and terminals are provided there, so all tasks may be performed).
Added by Alena Kniazeva, modified by Alex Litvinov

answer_llm:
If you can't install `tflite_runtime`, you can try these alternatives:

* **Use a compatible Python version:** `tflite_runtime` only supports specific Python versions. Check the available combinations and switch to a compatible version.
* **Try pre-built wheels:** The course provides pre-built wheels for different setups. You can try installing the appropriate wheel using `pip`.
* **Use TensorFlow locally and Docker for testing:** If nothing else works, use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development and Docker for testing Lambda functions.
answer_orig:
Problem: When trying to install tflite_runtime with
!pip install --extra-index-url https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/ tflite_runtime
one gets an error message above.
Solution:
fflite_runtime is only available for the os-python version combinations that can be found here: https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
your combination must be missing here
you can see if any of these work for you https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
and install the needed one using pip
eg
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
as it is done in the lectures code:
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/mlbookcamp-code/blob/master/course-zoomcamp/09-serverless/code/Dockerfile#L4
Alternatively, use a virtual machine (with VM VirtualBox, for example) with a Linux system. The other way is to run a code at a virtual machine within cloud service, for example you can use Vertex AI Workbench at GCP (notebooks and terminals are provided there, so all tasks may be performed).
Added by Alena Kniazeva, modified by Alex Litvinov
question: What alternatives do I have if I cannot install tflite_runtime on my current system?

answer_llm: Use the command `docker image save <image-name> -o <name-of-tar-file.tar>` to save a Docker image to your local machine.
answer_orig:
The docker image can be saved/exported to tar format in local machine using the below command:
docker image save <image-name> -o <name-of-tar-file.tar>
The individual layers of the docker image for the filesystem content can be viewed by extracting the layer.tar present in the <name-of-tar-file.tar> created from above.
Sumeet Lalla

answer_llm: This FAQ database section focuses on AWS permissions and serverless deep learning setup. It does not contain instructions on how to sign in to the AWS Console.
answer_orig:
Sign in to the AWS Console: Log in to the AWS Console.
Navigate to IAM: Go to the IAM service by clicking on "Services" in the top left corner and selecting "IAM" under the "Security, Identity, & Compliance" section.
Create a new policy: In the left navigation pane, select "Policies" and click on "Create policy."
Select the service and actions:
Click on "JSON" and copy and paste the JSON policy you provided earlier for the specific ECR actions.
Review and create the policy:
Click on "Review policy."
Provide a name and description for the policy.
Click on "Create policy."
JSON policy:
{
"Version": "2012-10-17",
"Statement": [
{
"Sid": "VisualEditor0",
"Effect": "Allow",
"Action": [
"ecr:CreateRepository",
"ecr:GetAuthorizationToken",
"ecr:BatchCheckLayerAvailability",
"ecr:BatchGetImage",
"ecr:InitiateLayerUpload",
"ecr:UploadLayerPart",
"ecr:CompleteLayerUpload",
"ecr:PutImage"
],
"Resource": "*"
}
]
}
Added by: Daniel Muñoz-Viveros

answer_llm:
Add these lines to `vim /etc/docker/daemon.json`:
```json
{
"dns": ["8.8.8.8", "8.8.4.4"]
}
```
Then restart Docker using: `sudo service docker restart`
question: What should I do if I encounter a Docker Temporary failure in name resolution during the Serverless Deep Learning section?

answer_llm:
To resolve Docker name resolution issues, add the Google DNS server addresses to the Docker daemon configuration file:

1. Open the Docker daemon configuration file with a text editor: `vim /etc/docker/daemon.json`
2. Add the following lines to the file:
```json
{
"dns": ["8.8.8.8", "8.8.4.4"]
}
```
3. Save the changes and restart Docker: `sudo service docker restart`
question: How can I resolve Docker name resolution issues?
What lines do I need to add to /etc/docker/daemon.json to fix DNS problems?

answer_llm: To test AWS Lambda locally with Docker, use the AWS Runtime Interface Emulator (RIE). Ensure your Docker image is built from the base AWS Lambda image (e.g., `FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10`). When running your Docker container, map port 9000 to 8080. You can then send test events to `http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations` using curl.
answer_orig:
This deployment setup can be tested locally using AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator).
Basically, if your Docker image was built upon base AWS Lambda image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10) - just use certain ports for “docker run” and a certain “localhost link” for testing:
docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name
This command runs the image as a container and starts up an endpoint locally at:
localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations
Post an event to the following endpoint using a curl command:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{}'
Examples of curl testing:
* windows testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d "{\"url\": \"https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg\"}"
* unix testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{"url": "https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg"}'
If during testing you encounter an error like this:
# {"errorMessage": "Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable", "errorType": "Runtime.MarshalError", "requestId": "7ea5d17a-e0a2-48d5-b747-a16fc530ed10", "stackTrace": []}
just turn your response at lambda_handler() to string - str(result).
Added by Andrii Larkin
question: What setup is needed to test AWS Lambda with Docker locally?

answer_llm: This question cannot be answered from the given context. The context focuses on building, testing, and deploying Docker images for AWS Lambda, but it does not explain how to run an image as a container specifically for AWS Lambda.
answer_orig:
This deployment setup can be tested locally using AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator).
Basically, if your Docker image was built upon base AWS Lambda image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10) - just use certain ports for “docker run” and a certain “localhost link” for testing:
docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name
This command runs the image as a container and starts up an endpoint locally at:
localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations
Post an event to the following endpoint using a curl command:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{}'
Examples of curl testing:
* windows testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d "{\"url\": \"https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg\"}"
* unix testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{"url": "https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg"}'
If during testing you encounter an error like this:
# {"errorMessage": "Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable", "errorType": "Runtime.MarshalError", "requestId": "7ea5d17a-e0a2-48d5-b747-a16fc530ed10", "stackTrace": []}
just turn your response at lambda_handler() to string - str(result).
Added by Andrii Larkin

question: What should I do if my test.py script in section 9 depends on the tensorflow library?

answer_llm:
One of the most common reasons for the error "'No module named 'tensorflow'" is that **tensorflow.lite** is still being imported from **tensorflow**. 

To fix this, change `import tensorflow.lite as tflite` to `import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite`.

answer_llm:
To resolve issues with installing 'pip install tflite_runtime' from GitHub wheel links, download the desired '.whl' file to your project directory. Then, modify your Dockerfile to include these lines:

```dockerfile
COPY <file-name> .
RUN pip install <file-name>
```

Replace `<file-name>` with the actual name of your downloaded '.whl' file. This method ensures the wheel file is accessible and installed correctly within your Docker image.

answer_llm: The provided context highlights resources for installing TensorFlow with CUDA support in WSL2, emphasizing the use of Windows Nvidia drivers and directing to the official TensorFlow installation guide for Linux (specifically step 4 for CUDA installation within an environment) and Nvidia's documentation for CUDA installation in WSL2.
answer_orig:
Running a CNN on your CPU can take a long time and once you’ve run out of free time on some cloud providers, it’s time to pay up. Both can be tackled by installing tensorflow with CUDA support on your local machine if you have the right hardware.
I was able to get it working by using the following resources:
CUDA on WSL :: CUDA Toolkit Documentation (nvidia.com)
Install TensorFlow with pip
Start Locally | PyTorch
I included the link to PyTorch so that you can get that one installed and working too while everything is fresh on your mind. Just select your options, and for Computer Platform, I chose CUDA 11.7 and it worked for me.
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm:
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook: 
```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```
This solution resolved most "Allocator ran out of memory" errors for the user who suggested it, though they still encountered the error once on a subsequent run.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe
question: What should I do if I get Allocator ran out of memory errors while running TensorFlow on my machine?

answer_llm:
To resolve memory allocation issues in TensorFlow on a machine with an Nvidia GPU, you can add the following code snippet at the beginning of your notebook:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
  tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
  # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
  pass
```

This code snippet configures TensorFlow to allocate only as much GPU memory as needed, preventing it from consuming all available memory.
answer_orig:

question: How can I configure TensorFlow to solve memory allocation issues on my machine?

answer_llm:
To potentially improve performance if you encounter memory errors, configure TensorFlow to allow GPU memory growth:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
  tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
  # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
  pass
```

This code snippet, designed for systems with Nvidia GPUs, helps manage memory allocation.

answer_llm:
```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()

session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

This code snippet was reported to address "Allocator ran out of memory" errors when running TensorFlow code.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm: A "TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly." error might occur due to an incompatible protobuf version.
answer_orig:
In session 10.3, when creating the virtual environment with pipenv and trying to run the script gateway.py, you might get this error:
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
More information: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/news/2022-05-06#python-updates
This will happen if your version of protobuf is one of the newer ones. As a workaround, you can fix the protobuf version to an older one. In my case I got around the issue by creating the environment with:
pipenv install --python 3.9.13 requests grpcio==1.42.0 flask gunicorn \
keras-image-helper tensorflow-protobuf==2.7.0 protobuf==3.19.6
Added by Ángel de Vicente


answer_llm:
This question is specific to WSL, and the provided context only offers a solution within that scope. 

To resolve the "Cannot connect to the Docker daemon" error in WSL:

1. **Check Docker Desktop's WSL Integration:** Go to Docker Desktop settings, click on "Resources", then "WSL Integration". 
2. **Enable Additional Distros:**  Make sure the checkbox for your WSL distribution is enabled. It's advised to enable this even if it's the default WSL distro.
answer_orig:
Due to the uncertainties associated with machines, sometimes you can get the error message like this when you try to run a docker command:
”Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?”
Solution: The solution is simple. The Docker Desktop might no longer be connecting to the WSL Linux distro. What you need to do is go to your Docker Desktop setting and then click on resources. Under resources, click on WSL Integration. You will get a tab like the image below:
Just enable additional distros. That’s all. Even if the additional distro is the same as the default WSL distro.
Odimegwu David

answer_llm:
If the HPA instance is not running properly, even after installing the latest Metrics Server, and the targets still appear as <unknown>, you should edit the metrics server deployment by running: 
```
kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
```
Then, add the line `- --kubelet-insecure-tls` within the `args` section, save the file, and run:
```
kubectl get hpa
```
answer_orig:
In case the HPA instance does not run correctly even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server from the components.yaml manifest with:
>>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
And the targets still appear as <unknown>
Run >>kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
And search for this line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add this line in the middle:  - --kubelet-insecure-tls
So that it stays like this:
args:
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Save and run again >>kubectl get hpa
Added by Marilina Orihuela

question: What should I do if the HPA instance does not run even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server?

answer_llm:
To fix the "<unknown>" target issue in your HPA instance, you can try two solutions:

1. **Edit the metrics-server deployment:**
    - Run `kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server`
    - Find the line `args: - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname`
    - Add `- --kubelet-insecure-tls` in the middle:
    ```
    args:
    - --kubelet-insecure-tls
    - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
    ```
    - Save and run `kubectl get hpa`

2. **Apply a pre-configured metrics server deployment:**
    - Run `kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml`
    - This deployment file already includes the `- --kubelet-insecure-tls` option.

To resolve the 'Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied' error, try using the `--user` option with the `pip install` command. For example:

`pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0` 

Alternatively, check the permissions of the directory where you are trying to install the packages.
answer_orig:
When I run pip install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0 to install the libraries in windows machine,  I was getting the below error :
ERROR: Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied: 'C:\\Users\\Asia\\anaconda3\\Lib\\site-packages\\google\\protobuf\\internal\\_api_implementation.cp39-win_amd64.pyd'
Consider using the `--user` option or check the permissions.
Solution description :
I was able to install the libraries using below command:
pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0
Asia Saeed

Consider using the `--user` option or check the permissions.
Solution description :
I was able to install the libraries using below command:
pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0

If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:

Solution description:
Issue has been resolved by downgrading protobuf to version 3.20.1.
pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1

answer_llm:
To install kubectl on Windows, you can use the curl command to download the kubectl binary. You can find the specific commands for this on the Kubernetes documentation website: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows.

After downloading the executable, you need to move it to a specific folder on your C drive and add that folder to your PATH environment variable.
answer_orig:
To install kubectl on windows using the terminal in vscode (powershell), I followed this tutorial: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff
I first downloaded kubectl with curl, with these command lines: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows
At step 3, I followed the tutorial with the copy of the exe file in a specific folder on C drive.
Then I added this folder path to PATH in my environment variables.
Kind can be installed the same way with the curl command on windows, by specifying a folder that will be added to the path environment variable.
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

answer_llm:
First, launch a powershell terminal with administrator privilege. Then, install the choco library by running the following command: 
```powershell
Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process -Force; [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol -bor 3072; iex ((New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://chocolatey.org/install.ps1'))
```
answer_orig:
First you need to launch a powershell terminal with administrator privilege.
For this we need to install choco library first through the following syntax in powershell:
Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process -Force; [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol -bor 3072; iex ((New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://chocolatey.org/install.ps1'))
Krishna Anand

answer_llm: Install Go from https://go.dev/doc/install and confirm the installation by typing "go version" in the Command Prompt. Then, install Kind by running the command: "go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0". Finally, confirm the installation by running "kind --version".
answer_orig:
If you are having challenges installing Kind through the Windows Powershell as provided on the website and Choco Library as I did, you can simply install Kind through Go.
> Download and Install Go (https://go.dev/doc/install)
> Confirm installation by typing the following in Command Prompt -  go version
> Proceed by installing Kind by following this command - go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0
>Confirm Installation kind --version
It works perfectly.

answer_llm: The provided context describes a 'connection refused' error when using 'kubectl get service', but it suggests that the solution involves deleting and recreating the Kubernetes cluster using 'kind' commands. It does not offer a direct solution for resolving the 'localhost:8080' connection refusal.
answer_orig:
I ran into an issue where kubectl wasn't working.
I kept getting the following error:
kubectl get service
The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused - did you specify the right host or port?
I searched online for a resolution, but everyone kept talking about creating an environment variable and creating some admin.config file in my home directory.
All hogwash.
The solution to my problem was to just start over.
kind delete cluster
rm -rf ~/.kube
kind create cluster
Now when I try the same command again:
kubectl get service
NAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGE
kubernetes   ClusterIP   10.96.0.1    <none>        443/TCP   53s
Added by Martin Uribe
question: How can I resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl?

answer_llm: Martin Uribe resolved a "connection refused" error when using kubectl by deleting the existing cluster, removing the .kube directory, and creating a new cluster.

answer_llm:
Martin Uribe resolved the 'The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' error by deleting and recreating his Kubernetes cluster using the following commands:

```
kind delete cluster
rm -rf ~/.kube
kind create cluster
```

kubectl get service
The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused - did you specify the right host or port?
I searched online for a resolution, but everyone kept talking about creating an environment variable and creating some admin.config file in my home directory.
All hogwash.
The solution to my problem was to just start over.
kind delete cluster
rm -rf ~/.kube
kind create cluster
Now when I try the same command again:
kubectl get service
NAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGE
kubernetes   ClusterIP   10.96.0.1    <none>        443/TCP   53s
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm: After removing images, you also need to run `docker system prune`. Deleting docker images does not actually free up any space.
answer_orig:
Problem description
Due to experimenting back and forth so much without care for storage, I just ran out of it on my 30-GB AWS instance.
My first reflex was to remove some zoomcamp directories, but of course those are mostly code so it didn’t help much.
Solution description
> docker images
revealed that I had over 20 GBs worth of superseded / duplicate models lying around, so I proceeded to > docker rmi
a bunch of those — but to no avail!
It turns out that deleting docker images does not actually free up any space as you might expect. After removing images, you also need to run
> docker system prune
See also: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36799718/why-removing-docker-containers-and-images-does-not-free-up-storage-space-on-wind
Added by Konrad Mühlberg
question: How can I solve the issue of running out of storage after building many docker images?

answer_llm: Deleting Docker images doesn't free up space because the disk space is marked as reclaimable, but not actually released. `docker system prune` is needed to reclaim the space.

answer_llm: The "m" in CPU values within Kubernetes deployment.yaml files stands for "milliCPU". A milliCPU represents one thousandth of a CPU core. For instance, a value of "100m" signifies that the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, equivalent to 0.1 of a CPU core.
answer_orig:
In Kubernetes resource specifications, such as CPU requests and limits, the "m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power. It represents one thousandth of a CPU core.
cpu: "100m" means the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.1 CPU core.
cpu: "500m" means the container has a CPU limit of 500 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.5 CPU core.
These values are specified in milliCPUs to allow fine-grained control over CPU resources. It allows you to express CPU requirements and limits in a more granular way, especially in scenarios where your application might not need a full CPU core.
Added by Andrii Larkin

You should specify the cluster name with the -n flag. For example:

```
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
```

Make sure to replace "clothing-model" with the actual name of your kind cluster.

answer_llm:
To load a Docker image into a named kind cluster, use the command `kind -n <cluster-name> load docker-image <image-name>:<tag>`. 

Make sure to replace `<cluster-name>` with the actual name of your cluster and `<image-name>:<tag>` with the relevant image details.

answer_llm: The downloaded executable's default name is `kind-windows-amd64.exe`. Rename it to `kind.exe`, place it in a specific folder, and add the folder to your PATH.
answer_orig:
Problem: I download kind from the next command:
curl.exe -Lo kind-windows-amd64.exe https://kind.sigs.k8s.io/dl/v0.17.0/kind-windows-amd64
When I try
kind --version
I get: 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file
Solution: The default name of executable is kind-windows-amd64.exe, so that you have to rename this file to  kind.exe. Put this file in specific folder, and add it to PATH
Alejandro Aponte

answer_llm:
To resolve the "TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'unbound_message'" error, try installing an older version of Flask (Flask==2.1.3) using pipenv:

```bash
pipenv install Flask==2.1.3
```

This error usually arises from compatibility issues between newer versions of Flask (2.2.2 in this case) and older versions of Werkzeug (2.2.2).
answer_orig:
Problem Description:
In video 10.3, when I was testing a flask service, I got the above error. I ran docker run .. in one terminal. When in second terminal I run python gateway.py, I get the above error.
Solution: This error has something to do with versions of Flask and Werkzeug. I got the same error, if I just import flask with from flask import Flask.
By running pip freeze > requirements.txt,I found that their versions are Flask==2.2.2 and Werkzeug==2.2.2. This error appears while using an old version of werkzeug (2.2.2) with new version of flask (2.2.2). I solved it by pinning version of Flask into an older version with pipenv install Flask==2.1.3.
Added by Bhaskar Sarma
question: What solution can you offer for the TypeError related to 'unbound_message' when importing Flask?

answer_llm:
This error is related to an incompatibility between Flask versions 2.2.2 and Werkzeug 2.2.2. To resolve this, try installing an older version of Flask (2.1.3) using pipenv:

```bash
pipenv install Flask==2.1.3
```

Solution: This error has something to do with versions of Flask and Werkzeug. I got the same error, if I just import flask with from flask import Flask.
By running pip freeze > requirements.txt,I found that their versions are Flask==2.2.2 and Werkzeug==2.2.2. This error appears while using an old version of werkzeug (2.2.2) with new version of flask (2.2.2). I solved it by pinning version of Flask into an older version with pipenv install Flask==2.1.3.
Added by Bhaskar Sarma
question: What versions of Flask and Werkzeug were causing the 'unbound_message' TypeError?

answer_llm: Bhaskar Sarma suggested solving the "TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'unbound_message'" by pinning the Flask version to an older version, specifically Flask==2.1.3, using the command "pipenv install Flask==2.1.3". This error occurs due to incompatibility between newer versions of Flask (2.2.2 in this case) and older versions of Werkzeug (2.2.2).
answer_orig:
Problem Description:
In video 10.3, when I was testing a flask service, I got the above error. I ran docker run .. in one terminal. When in second terminal I run python gateway.py, I get the above error.
Solution: This error has something to do with versions of Flask and Werkzeug. I got the same error, if I just import flask with from flask import Flask.
By running pip freeze > requirements.txt,I found that their versions are Flask==2.2.2 and Werkzeug==2.2.2. This error appears while using an old version of werkzeug (2.2.2) with new version of flask (2.2.2). I solved it by pinning version of Flask into an older version with pipenv install Flask==2.1.3.
Added by Bhaskar Sarma

answer_llm: The command `aws ecr get-login --no-include-email` is outdated. You should use `aws ecr get-login-password` to get the password for logging in.
answer_orig:
As per AWS documentation:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/docker-push-ecr-image.html
You need to do: (change the fields in red)
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
Alternatively you can run the following command without changing anything given you have a default region configured
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
Added by Humberto Rodriguez

answer_llm:
To solve the TensorFlow Serving error on an Apple M1 Mac, use the `bitnami/tensorflow-serving` base image instead of the `tensorflow/serving` image. 

You can launch it with `docker run`:

```
docker run -d \
--name tf_serving \
-p 8500:8500 \
-p 8501:8501 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
-e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
```

Or with a `docker-compose.yaml` file:

```
version: '3'
services:
  tf_serving:
    image: bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
    volumes:
      - ${PWD}/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1
    ports:
      - 8500:8500
      - 8501:8501
    environment:
      - TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model
```

Then run it with `docker compose up`.
answer_orig:
While trying to run the docker code on M1:
docker run --platform linux/amd64 -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
It outputs the error:
Error:
Status: Downloaded newer image for tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
[libprotobuf FATAL external/com_google_protobuf/src/google/protobuf/generated_message_reflection.cc:2345] CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'
what():  CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
qemu: uncaught target signal 6 (Aborted) - core dumped
/usr/bin/tf_serving_entrypoint.sh: line 3:     8 Aborted                 tensorflow_model_server --port=8500 --rest_api_port=8501 --model_name=${MODEL_NAME} --model_base_path=${MODEL_BASE_PATH}/${MODEL_NAME} "$@"
Solution
docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest
docker run -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
See more here: https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm
Added by Daniel Egbo

answer_llm:
- Delete the HPA using: `kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa`
- Apply the metrics server configuration: `kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml`
- Recreate the HPA.
answer_orig:
Problem: CPU metrics Shows Unknown
NAME         REFERENCE           TARGETS         MINPODS   MAXPODS   REPLICAS   AGE
credit-hpa   Deployment/credit   <unknown>/20%   1         3         1          18s
FailedGetResourceMetric       2m15s (x169 over 44m)  horizontal-pod-autoscaler  failed to get cpu utilization: unable to get metrics for resource cpu: unable to fetch metrics from resource metrics API:
Solution:
-> Delete HPA (kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa)
-> kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
-> Create HPA
This should solve the cpu metrics report issue.
Added by Priya V

-> kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
-> Create HPA
This should solve the cpu metrics report issue.
Added by Priya V

answer_llm: If you're running kubectl version > 1.25.0 and getting errors during KServe installation due to Istio, download the "quick_install.bash" script without running it. Edit the Istio and Knative versions in the script to match the matrix on the KServe website, then run the script.
answer_orig:
Problem description:
Running this:
curl -s "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kserve/kserve/release-0.9/hack/quick_install.sh" | bash
Fails with errors because of istio failing to update resources, and you are on kubectl > 1.25.0.
Check kubectl version with kubectl version
Solution description
Edit the file “quick_install.bash” by downloading it with curl without running bash. Edit the versions of Istio and Knative as per the matrix on the KServe website.
Run the bash script now.
Added by Andrew Katoch

Export the notebook into a script

question: Where can I find a sample of the midterm project?

answer_llm:
For the midterm project, you need to:

1. **Choose a problem and dataset:** Find an interesting problem and a corresponding dataset.
2. **Describe the problem and solution:** Explain the problem and how a model can be used to address it.
3. **Prepare data and perform EDA:** Prepare your data and conduct exploratory data analysis, analyzing important features.
4. **Train and tune models:** Train multiple models, fine-tune their performance, and select the best-performing one.
5. **Export the notebook to a script:** Convert your Jupyter Notebook into a Python script.
6. **Deploy the model locally:** Package your model into a web service and deploy it locally using Docker.

Bonus points are awarded for deploying the service to the cloud.

question: Where can I find datasets to use for my project?

answer_llm:
1. **Problem and Dataset:** Choose a problem you find interesting and find a relevant dataset.
2. **Problem Description:** Describe the chosen problem and explain how a machine learning model can be used to address it.
3. **Data Preparation and EDA:** Prepare the data and perform exploratory data analysis (EDA) to analyze important features.
4. **Model Training and Selection:** Train multiple machine learning models, fine-tune their performance, and select the best-performing model.
5. **Script Export:** Export the Jupyter Notebook containing your project code into a Python script.
6. **Web Service and Deployment:** Deploy your trained model as a web service using Docker for local deployment.
7. **Bonus:** Deploy the web service to a cloud platform for additional bonus points.

answer_llm:
You can find the three projects you've been assigned to review by following these steps:

1. **Calculate your hash value:**
    - Use the provided Python code and replace the example email with your own.
    - Run the code to get your unique "Hashed Email (SHA-1)" value. 
2. **Open the project spreadsheet:**
    - Access the spreadsheet using the provided link.
3. **Find your assigned projects:**
    - Search the "reviewer_hash" column for three instances of your calculated hash value. 
    - The projects associated with those entries are the ones you need to review.
answer_orig:
I am not sure how the project evaluate assignment works? Where do I find this? I have access to all the capstone 2 project, perhaps, I can randomly pick any to review.
Answer:
The link provided for example (2023/Capstone link ): https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdgoepohpgbM4MWTAHWuXa6r3NXKnxKcg4NDOm0bElAdXdnnA/viewform contains a list of all submitted projects to be evaluated. More specific, you are to review 3 assigned peer projects. In the spreadsheet are 3 hash values of your assigned peer projects. However, you need to derive the your hash value of your email address and find the value on the spreadsheet under the (reviewer_hash) heading.
To calculate your hash value run the python code below:
from hashlib import sha1
def compute_hash(email):
return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
# Example usage **** enter your email below (Example1@gmail.com)****
email = "Example1@gmail.com"
hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
print("Original Email:", email)
print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
Edit the above code to replace Example1@gmail.com as your email address
Store and run the above python code from your terminal. See below as the Hashed Email (SHA-1) value
You then go to the link: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true
Lastly, copy the “Hashed Email (SHA-1): bd9770be022dede87419068aa1acd7a2ab441675” value and search for 3 identical entries. There you should see your peer project to be reviewed.
By Emmanuel Ayeni
question: How do I find the projects I need to review for the capstone?

answer_llm:
1. **Edit the Python code:** Replace "Example1@gmail.com" with your email address in the provided code snippet.
2. **Run the code:** Save the code as a Python file (e.g., `hash_calculator.py`) and run it from your terminal using the command `python hash_calculator.py`.
3. **Copy the hash:** The output of the code will display your hashed email address under "Hashed Email (SHA-1):". Copy this value.
4. **Go to the spreadsheet:** Open the provided Google Sheets link.
5. **Search for your hash:** Use the spreadsheet's search function (Ctrl+F or Cmd+F) to find three identical entries of your copied hashed email address under the "reviewer_hash" heading. These entries correspond to the peer projects assigned to you for review.

answer_llm: The context provided in the FAQ database does not contain information about how to avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with a Docker container. Therefore, I cannot answer your question.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD
question: How can I avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with my Docker container?

answer_llm:
Waitress runs your `app.py` in a different module, not in `__main__` like when you run the script directly. 

When pickle saves your model, it stores a reference to your custom class using the `__main__` module. When loading the model under waitress, pickle can't find the class in the `__main__` module because waitress uses a different module.

question: What causes pickle to throw an attribute error when running a Docker container with waitress?

answer_llm: When using waitress, it loads the module containing your prediction code and tries to unpickle the saved model. During pickling, the custom class was referenced within the `__main__` module's namespace. Waitress doesn't maintain this context, so it cannot locate the class definition.

question: Why does pickle work with Flask but not with waitress for my custom column transformer class?

answer_llm: To avoid pickle errors related to custom classes when using waitress, move the custom class definition to a separate Python module. Then, import this module in both the script where you save your model (e.g., `train.py`) and the script where you load the model for predictions (e.g., `predict.py`). This ensures the class is referenced consistently regardless of waitress's module loading behavior.

answer_llm: If Bento fails to import the 'service' module with the error message "'No module named 'sklearn'", you should make sure that you have written "scikit-learn" instead of "sklearn" in the packages list within your bentofile.yaml.
answer_orig:
I was getting the below error message when I was trying to create docker image using bentoml
[bentoml-cli] `serve` failed: Failed loading Bento from directory /home/bentoml/bento: Failed to import module "service": No module named 'sklearn'
Solution description
The cause was because , in bentofile.yaml, I wrote sklearn instead of scikit-learn. Issue was fixed after I modified the packages list as below.
packages: # Additional pip packages required by the service
- xgboost
- scikit-learn
- pydantic
Asia Saeed

answer_llm: Setting `DictVectorizer` or `OHE` to sparse during training and storing it in the BentoML model might be the cause. This leads to inconsistent sparse matrix sizes during inference, which can't be batched.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: What might be the cause of a long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML?

answer_llm: When using DictVectorizer or One-Hot Encoding (OHE) with the sparse matrix option enabled during training, the resulting sparse matrices might have varying sizes in a BentoML production environment. This happens because each input could be converted into a sparse matrix of a different size, making batching impossible due to inconsistent lengths. To resolve this, set the 'batchable' parameter to 'False' in the BentoML model signatures during the model saving step in your 'train.py' script.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: Why do I get different sized sparse matrices in BentoML production when using DictVectorizer or OHE during training?

answer_llm: To prevent errors in a production setting with BentoML, set the `batchable` parameter to `False` within your BentoML model signatures during the model saving process in your `train.py` script. This is particularly important when dealing with scenarios where your training pipeline includes components like `DictVectorizer` or One-Hot Encoding set to produce sparse matrices.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: What should I set batchable to in bentoml model signatures to avoid errors in production?

answer_llm: The `train.py` module should be modified to make BentoML production work if DictVectorizer or OHE is set to sparse.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: Which module should be modified to make bentoml production work if DictVectorizer or OHE is set to sparse?

answer_llm: Setting `DictVectorizer` or `OHE` to sparse during training and storing it in a pipeline or custom object when saving the BentoML model can cause this. This leads to inconsistent sparse matrix sizes during inference, making batching impossible.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)

answer_llm: You can try compressing the model using joblib. Using joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6) will compress the model using zlib. Keep in mind compressing the model could take a few minutes.
answer_orig:
If your model is too big for github one option is to try and compress the model using joblib. For example joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6) will use zlib to compress the model. Just note this could take a few moments as the model is being compressed.
Quinn Avila
question: What should I do if my model is too big for GitHub?

answer_llm: To compress a large model for GitHub, use the `joblib` library. For instance, `joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6)` will compress your model using `zlib`. Keep in mind that compressing the model may take some time.
answer_orig:

question: Is there a specific tool mentioned for compressing big models?

answer_llm:
```python
joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6)) 
```

This uses `zlib` to compress the model and will save it to `model_filename`. Keep in mind that compressing the model could take a few moments.
answer_orig:
If your model is too big for github one option is to try and compress the model using joblib. For example joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6) will use zlib to compress the model. Just note this could take a few moments as the model is being compressed.
Quinn Avila

answer_llm: If you are unable to install `tflite_runtime` in a pipenv environment, ensure that your Python version is compatible by checking the available versions at https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/. If your setup is incompatible, try installing a version from https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite using pip. For example: `pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl`. If all else fails, use TensorFlow's TFLite for local development and Docker for testing Lambda.
answer_orig:
I am getting this error message when I tried to install tflite in a pipenv environment
Error:  An error occurred while installing tflite_runtime!
Error text:
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement tflite_runtime (from versions: none)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for tflite_runtime
This version of tflite do not run on python 3.10, the way we can make it work is by install python 3.9, after that it would install the tflite_runtime without problem.
Pastor Soto
Check all available versions here:
https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
If you don’t find a combination matching your setup, try out the options at
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
which you can install as shown in the lecture, e.g.
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
Finally, if nothing works, use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development, and use Docker for testing Lambda.
Rileen Sinha (based on discussions on Slack)

question: Where can I check all available versions of tflite_runtime?

answer_llm:
If you're having trouble installing Kind using the standard methods (Windows Powershell or Choco Library), you can try installing it via the Go package:

1. Download and install Go from [https://go.dev/doc/install](https://go.dev/doc/install).
2. Verify your Go installation by typing `go version` in your Command Prompt.
3. Install Kind by running the command: `go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0`.
4. Confirm the installation by running `kind --version`.

answer_llm:
Add `?raw=true` after `.jpg` in the URL. 

For example:
`url = ‘https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true’`
answer_orig:
In deploying model part, I wanted to test my model locally on a test-image data and I had this silly error after the following command:
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg'
X = preprocessor.from_url(url)
I got the error:
UnidentifiedImageError: cannot identify image file <_io.BytesIO object at 0x7f797010a590>
Solution:
Add ?raw=true after .jpg in url. E.g. as below
url = ‘https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true’
Bhaskar Sarma

answer_llm: The function `dv.get_feature_names()` is being deprecated. Use `list(dv.get_feature_names_out())` instead.
answer_orig:
Problem: In the course this function worked to get the features from the dictVectorizer instance: dv.get_feature_names(). But in my computer did not work. I think it has to do with library versions and but apparently that function will be deprecated soon:
Old: https://scikit-learn.org/0.22/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.html#sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.get_feature_names
New: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.html#sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.get_feature_names
Solution: change the line dv.get_feature_names() to list(dv.get_feature_names_out))
Ibai Irastorza
question: Why doesn't dv.get_feature_names() work on my computer?

answer_llm: Yes, library versions can affect the `dv.get_feature_names()` function. Using different versions of Scikit-learn when creating a virtual environment can lead to version conflicts and break your code. Ensure that your model and DictVectorizer files are created using the same Scikit-learn version used in your project.

New: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.html#sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.get_feature_names
Solution: change the line dv.get_feature_names() to list(dv.get_feature_names_out))
Ibai Irastorza

answer_llm:
1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column to strings using `df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)`.
2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column (e.g., "jan", "feb") into numeric month representation (e.g., "1", "2", etc.) using `map()`.
3. Combine `day_of_the_month` and `month_of_the_year` into a datetime object:
 ```python
 df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
 dict(
 year='2055',
 month=df['month'],
 day=df['day']
 )
 )
 ```
4. Extract the day of the year using: `df['day_of_year']=df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear`
answer_orig:
Problem description: I have one column day_of_the_month . It has values 1, 2, 20, 25 etc. and int . I have a second column month_of_the_year. It has values jan, feb, ..dec. and are string. I want to convert these two columns into one column day_of_the_year and I want them to be int. 2 and jan should give me 2, i.e. 2nd day of the year, 1 and feb should give me 32, i.e. 32 nd day of the year. What is the simplest pandas-way to do it?
Solution description:
convert dtype in day_of_the_month column from int to str with df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
convert month_of_the_year column in jan, feb ...,dec into 1,2, ..,12 string using map()
convert day and month into a datetime object with:
df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
dict(
year='2055',
month=df['month'],
day=df['day']
)
)
get day of year with: df['day_of_year']=df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
(Bhaskar Sarma)
question: How can I convert day_of_the_month and month_of_the_year columns into a single day_of_the_year column in pandas?

answer_llm: Bhaskar Sarma suggests converting the day and month columns into a datetime object, then using the 'dt.dayofyear' function to get the day of the year.

question: How do I transform month_of_the_year values like 'jan' and 'feb' into integers in pandas?

answer_llm:
First, convert the 'month_of_the_year' column (e.g., 'jan', 'feb') into string representations of their corresponding numerical values (e.g., '1', '2'). Then, use `pd.to_datetime` with a dictionary containing the year, month, and day columns. 

Here's an example:

```python
df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
dict(
year='2055',
month=df['month'],
day=df['day']
)
) 
```

answer_llm:
1. Install Nvidia drivers: https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx.
2. Install Anaconda prompt: https://www.anaconda.com/
3. Choose one of the following options:
    - Install the package ‘tensorflow-gpu’ in Anaconda.
    - Install TensorFlow using the instructions for Windows: https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#windows-native 
4. Install CUDA toolkit 11.x.x: https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive
5. Install cuDNN: https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download
answer_orig:
Install Nvidia drivers: https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx.
Windows:
Install Anaconda prompt https://www.anaconda.com/
Two options:
Install package ‘tensorflow-gpu’ in Anaconda
Install the Tensorflow way https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#windows-native
WSL/Linux:
WSL: Use the Windows Nvida drivers, do not touch that.
Two options:
Install the Tensorflow way https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1
Make sure to follow step 4 to install CUDA by environment

Install CUDA toolkit 11.x.x https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive
Install https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download

answer_llm: The order of matrices in multiplication matters because the resulting matrices from multiplying in a different order will be of different sizes and values.
answer_orig:
When multiplying matrices, the order of multiplication is important.
For example:
A (m x n) * B (n x p) = C (m x p)
B (n x p) * A (m x n) = D (n x n)
C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.
Baran Akın
question: Why is the order important in matrix multiplication?

answer_llm: The order in which you multiply matrices matters. Changing the order will likely change the resulting matrix's values and size.
